content.description: Start inside the bowl. Move out from the conglomerate that's under into crimpy face moves and top out at the shelf.
content.protection: couple of pads and a spotter
content.location: Few feet right of the concrete block in front of the bowl.

content.description:
I’ve always passed this line thinking, “this is the most obvious line on Fireplace Rock, why isn’t it popular/on mountain project?” Then I climbed it. 

Holy SAND. I’m convinced that all of the sand in the muscle beach area originated from the horizontal crack on this climb. The theoretical crux is the opening side pulls to get established into the crack, but the actual crux is dealing with all of the sand. 

 Resources online say that the chimney top out is optional, but have you really sent it if you didn’t top out? I’m convinced that this one could gain a star if it saw more traffic, the traverse is pumpy and fun, and the chimney is committing.
content.protection: Pad/spotter. Pressure washer if you have one.
content.location: Stand start on a side pull, then crank to another side pull directly above that’s just to the left of the obvious horizontal crack. Traverse the entire crack then top out through the giant offwidth chimney.

content.description: Start low under the roof on the obvious double cling. Cross over to the right on a crimp and reposition feet high to the left. Continue right and match on the big jug to finish out into chin ups.
content.protection: Couple of pads for the start, and a spotter.
content.location: To the right of reeds and under chin ups. Start deep under roof on the double cling.

content.description: This is probably the only 5.7 sport route that I know of at Sandrock. Bottom half has a buldge with pockets and positive holds which turns into a slab. Nice climb for the aspiring leader. If the bolts are chopped, just boulder this V0.
content.protection: 3 bolts. Open Shut. May be chopped depending on who is winning the war.
content.location: Look at the fireplace rock cave and go right. Go through a corridor between Fireplace Rock and the Shoe Box near the slab. Hang a left and you'll see this route on the valley side.

content.description: Climb the pocketed face. Different tricks for getting up and hitting the final holds.
content.location: Towards the left of this section. To the left of Water Torture, to the right of Bread Loaf (the arete). The pocketed face that looks like swiss cheese.

content.description: Right hand on high undercling, move up the water groove.
content.location: Obvious water groove to the right of the concrete block.

content.description: start under the roof, just right of reeds eliminate.  pull the lip and walk off.
content.location: fireplace rock just right of reeds eliminate

content.description: Start with sidepulls, climb straight up arete.
content.protection: Couple of pads and a spotter.
content.location: Far left arete of Fireplace, next to the non-technical scramble up to the top.

content.description:
First set of rocks at the end of the parking lot. From the other side you can scramble up and get the easiest view of the valley and Lake Weiss. 

  Great bouldering- a little break from the routes and something to do at night.
